field_edited_text.value:
In the beginning: This glittering, bubbling, sometimes violent
stream has, over the past three hundred years, acted as a mag-
net for the establishment of towns and turnpikes. It continues
to play a prominent role in the history of Baltimore City.

Its namesake, one David Jones, settled 380 acres along the
eastern banks of the stream in 1661; his settlement, Jones’
Town, is identified today as Old Town. Directly across the
Falls, along its western slopes, Baltimore Town was estab-
lished in 1729. By 1745, the two were jointed as the City of
Baltimore.

The available water power at the frequent falls, combined
with the early Jones Falls Turnpike, opened the Valley to
commerce. Flour mills and foundries were built where ter-
rain allowed. But the rugged side walls of the Valley and the
frequent flooding of the meadows have, from the beginning,
placed severe limits upon the Valley’s industrial development.

The coming of the railroad produced the incentive for major
textile mills; the Washington Cotton Manufacturers (now
Maryland Bolt and Nut) led the way in 1804. Horatio Gam-

Jones Falls Turnpike in the early nineteenth century.

Geological section, Green Spring Valley to Federal Hill.



Baltimore

Brandywine Terrace

Lake Roland
Coldspring Lane
28th-29th Streets

Green Spring
Valley 5




Wicomico
Terrace

vvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvv

PRA T O N A VAN ,x::‘::“:::::,;
Quartzite Gabbro
Limestone Gneiss Gneiss Gneiss

~~~~~~~~
b SRR R i YR )









briel built the Mount Vernon Mill near Cedar Avenue in 1847.
The Woodberry, Druid, and Clipper Mills followed in short
order. Baltimore soon became the world center for cotton
duck. The Clipper ships figure prominently in this mid-
nineteenth century era.

At the time of the Baltimore Riot in 1861, the Melvale rail-
road bridge over Jones Falls (just above Cold Spring Lane)
was burned. Because of its importance as the major supply
route south from Pennsylvania, this portion of the then
Maryland and Susquehanna Railroad was guarded by Union
Soldiers stationed at Camp Small throughout the Civil War.

Since the mid-nineteenth century, the trend of activity in the
Valley has been significantly directed toward public and in-
stitutional use. Some 1500 acres in park lands border the
Valley; a golf course, semi-public institutions, and private
recreational facilities have been built. The Jones Falls Ex-
pressway, another public facility for which planning began
almost thirty years ago, is the most recent event in the Valley
history.
